I'm Summer Jackson.

I'm a professor in the
Organizational Behavior Unit

here at Harvard Business School,
and I study organizational inequality.

So I look at social categories
such as race, class, and gender,

and their implications in workplaces for
people's hiring, promotion, and retention.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So workplace microaggressions as a
concept has been around since the 1970s.

Chester Pierce was one of the
first people to coin the term.

And then Derald Sue in the
1990s did a lot of work

to sort of bring it into the
more general consciousness.

But microaggressions at work
are basically any interaction,

verbal, paraverbal,
or sort of body language even related,

that can subtly subordinate
a person's identity.
So can make a person feel less than

because of one of their social
identities, and that could be their race,

their gender, their class, their sexual
orientation, or their able-bodiedness.

And they can often happen
unintentionally, right?

A person who's doing it
doesn't even know that they

have done that to another person,
which is what makes them so pernicious.

is it helps organizations understand

how to build resilience
when they do happen,
so they can come back even stronger.

If you think about what

You still have to work

But what you can do to try and

microaggression happens, is two things.

The first is, you can make sure
that every one of your employees

has a sort of shared sense
of work meaningfulness,

which means that they really understand
why their day to day work matters.

Because when a microaggression happens,
understanding that getting beyond it,

for society or for your community,

is one thing that can help

DEI norms and values.

for the most part, everyone is trying to
